chapter.title: Observation Practice
chapter.content:
In this unit you will practice making specific, objective observations for motivation and persistence strategies. We highly recommend that you develop your skills in this type of observation using the same video provided in Unit 1. This will allow you to use a new observation protocol featured in Unit 2 and also to benefit from comparing your observation notes with those of seasoned adult educators who viewed the same video.

chapter.title: Using an Observation Protocol
chapter.content:
Many teachers have limited experience observing other classes besides their own. Frequently, observers confuse observation with evaluation, or they focus only on what the teacher does rather than noting the activities, interactions, and behaviors of the students. In this course, you will practice doing observations that objectively describe what teachers and students are doing during instruction. Then you will consider what your observation tells you about the teacher's use of the principles.

To better prepare you for this next step, you will practice observing one of the lessons you have already viewed, focusing on careful description of what you see the teacher do to support students' motivation and persistence. The observation tool should be focused on the instructional practices you are striving to implement in the areas of motivation. This may require that you adapt an available observation tool by selecting a small subset of items so that the observer can stay focused on the target practices.

Let's return to view the writing class that you watched in Unit 1 and this time use the Observation Protocol. Download and print out a copy of the Observation Protocol (Word). For this practice you will only observe for 4 strategies. View the video, guided by the Observation Protocol. However, if you would prefer viewing videos of other classes, you have the option to select an alternative video (see the Suggested Alternatives page for suggestions).

chapter.title: Post-Viewing Questions
chapter.content:
Consider the video on Alternative Assessment in Unit 2 of this course as you address these questions:

  1. What is one “specific, concrete, and descriptive” observation you would share with the teacher? (Use the course thread in the LINCS Evidence-Based Professional Development Community of Practice to share your ideas with other practitioners and also see what previous course participants have observed.)

  2. How would your overall observation notes and feedback to Alicia have been different if you had focused your attention only on her and not the students? Jot down your ideas in your journal.

chapter.title: Compare Observation Notes
chapter.content:
What observers consider worth noting during an observation can have a large impact on what the observed teacher then pays attention to.

  • Read this set of Observation Notes to see what Jamie, another educator, noticed in Alicia’s class.

  • Notice what you and Jamie each commented on and think about how your discussions with the teacher Alicia would be similar or different. If you like, jot down key differences or similarities on the Observation Notes or in your journal.
